010package imagingbook.pub.color.quantize;
011
012import java.util.Arrays;
013import java.util.LinkedList;
014import java.util.List;
015
016import ij.IJ;
017import ij.ImagePlus;
018import ij.process.ByteProcessor;
019import ij.process.ColorProcessor;
020import ij.process.ImageProcessor;
021import imagingbook.lib.color.RgbUtils;
022
023/**
024 * This class implements color quantization based on the octree method. It is a
025 * re-factored version of an implementation (OctTreeOpImage.java) used in Sun's JAI 
026 * (Java Advanced Imaging) framework, which &ndash; in turn &ndash; is based on a 
027 * C implementation (quantize.c) authored by John Cristy in 1992 as part of 
028 * <a href="http://www.imagemagick.org/">ImageMagick</a>.
029 * The associated source code can be found 
030 * <a href="http://git.imagemagick.org/repos/ImageMagick/blob/master/MagickCore/quantize.c">
031 * here</a>, the original copyright note is provided at the bottom of this source file.
032 * 
033 * See also the abovementioned JAI implementation in
034 * <a href="https://java.net/projects/jai-core/sources/svn/content/trunk/src/share/classes/com/sun/media/jai/opimage/OctTreeOpImage.java">
035 * OctTreeOpImage.java</a>.
036 * 
037 * This implementation is similar but not identical to the original octree quantization algorithm proposed
038 * by Gervautz and Purgathofer [M. Gervautz and W. Purgathofer. "A simple method for color
039 * quantization: octree quantization", in A. Glassner (editor), Graphics Gems I, 
040 * pp. 287â€“293. Academic Press, New York (1990)].
041 * This implementation uses a modified strategy for pruning the octree for better efficiency.
042 * 
043 * "Quick quantization" means that original colors are mapped to their color index by simply
044 * finding the containing octree node. Otherwise, the closest quantized color (in terms of 
045 * Euclidean distance) is searched for, which is naturally slower.
046 * 
047 * @author WB
048 * @version 2017/01/03
049 */
050public class OctreeQuantizer implements ColorQuantizer {
051
052//      private final static int MAX_RGB = 255;
053        private final static int MAX_NODES = 262144 - 1; // = 2^18 - 1, was 266817;
054        private final static int MAX_TREE_DEPTH = 8;    // check, 7 enough?
055
056        private final int maxColors;    // max. number of distinct colors after quantization
057        
058        private final int nColors;              // final number of colors
059        private final TreeNode root;            // root node of the tree
060        
061        private int depth;                              // current depth of the tree
062        private int nodeCnt = 0;                // counts the number of nodes in the tree
063        private int colorCnt = 0;               // counts the number of colors in the cube (used for temp. counting)
064
065//      private final float[][] colormap;
066        private boolean quickQuantization = false;
067        
068        
069//      public static class Parameters {
070//              /** Maximum number of quantized colors. */
071//              public int maxColors = 16;
072//              /** Enable/disable quick quantization */
073//              public boolean quickQuantization = false;
074//              
075//              void check() {
076//                      if (maxColors < 2 || maxColors > 256) {
077//                              throw new IllegalArgumentException();
078//                      }
079//              }
080//      }
081
082        // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
083        
084        public OctreeQuantizer(ColorProcessor ip, int K) {
085                this((int[]) ip.getPixels(), K);
086        }
087        
088        public OctreeQuantizer(int[] pixels, int K) {
089                this.maxColors = K;
090                this.root = new TreeNode(null, 0);
091                this.depth = Math.min(Math.max(log2(maxColors) - 1, 2), MAX_TREE_DEPTH);// 2 <= depth <= maxTreeDepth
092                
093                int initColorCnt = addPixels(pixels);
094                
095                this.nColors = reduceTree(initColorCnt, pixels.length);
096        }
097        
098//      public OctreeQuantizer(int[] pixels) {
099//              this(pixels, new Parameters());
100//      }
101        
102        public void setQuickQuantization(boolean quickQuantization) {
103                this.quickQuantization = quickQuantization;
104        }
105        
106        // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
107        
108        @SuppressWarnings("unused")
109        private int addPixels(int[] pixels) {
110                for (int p : pixels) {
111                        addPixel(p);
112                        if (nodeCnt > MAX_NODES) { // a hard limit on the number of nodes in the tree
113                                root.pruneTree();
114                                depth--;
115                        }       
116                }
117                return colorCnt;
118        }
119
120        // walk the tree to depth, increasing the 'npixels' count in each node
121        private void addPixel(int p) {
122                TreeNode node = root;
123                node.nPixels++;
124                int[] rgb = RgbUtils.intToRgb(p);
125                for (int level = 1; level <= depth; level++) {
126                        int id = node.getChildId(rgb);
127                        if (node.childs[id] == null) {
128                                node = new TreeNode(node, id);  // create a new node at next level
129                        } 
130                        else {  // step to next level
131                                node = node.childs[id];
132                        }
133                        node.nPixels++;
134                }
135
136                // at level 'depth': update color statistics of this node
137                node.nUnique++;
138                
139                node.totalRed += rgb[0];
140                node.totalGrn += rgb[1];
141                node.totalBlu += rgb[2];
142        }
143
144        /**
145         * reduceTree() repeatedly prunes the tree until the number of
146         * nodes with unique > 0 is less than or equal to the maximum
147         * number of colors allowed in the output image.
148         * When a node to be pruned has offspring, the pruning
149         * procedure invokes itself recursively in order to prune the
150         * tree from the leaves upward.  The statistics of the node
151         * being pruned are always added to the corresponding data in
152         * that node's parent.  This retains the pruned node's color
153         * characteristics for later averaging.
154         * 
155         * @param initColorCnt 
156         *              The initial number of colors (leaves) in the octree.
157         * @param nSamples 
158         *              The total number of color samples used for creating the tree.
159         * @return
160         */
161        @SuppressWarnings("unused")
162        private int reduceTree(int initColorCnt, int nSamples) {
163                int minPixelCnt = Math.max(1,  nSamples / (maxColors * 8));
164                colorCnt = initColorCnt;
165                while (colorCnt > maxColors) {
166                        colorCnt = 0;   // for recounting the number of colors (leaves)
167                        minPixelCnt = root.reduceSparseNodes(minPixelCnt, Integer.MAX_VALUE);
168                }
169                return colorCnt;
170        }
171
172        private float[][] makeColorMap() {
173                List<float[]> colList = new LinkedList<>();
174                colorCnt = 0;   // used to store the color index in each node
175                root.collectColors(colList);
176                return colList.toArray(new float[0][]);
177        }
178        
179        /**
180         * Lists the octree nodes to System.out (intended for debugging only).
181         */
182        public void listNodes() {
183                root.listNodes();
184        }
185
186        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
187        
188        /**
189         * Represents a node in the octree.
190         */
191        private class TreeNode {
192                final TreeNode parent;          // reference to the parent node (null for the root node)
193                final TreeNode[] childs;        // references to child nodes
194                final int id;                   // branch index of this node at the parent node (0,...,7)
195                final int level;                // level of this node within the tree (root has level 0)
196                
197                int nChilds = 0;        // number of child nodes
198                int nPixels = 0;        // number of pixels represented by this node and all child nodes
199                int nUnique = 0;        // number of pixels represented by this node but none of the children
200
201                final int midRed;       // RGB color midpoint (center of this node in color space)
202                final int midGrn;
203                final int midBlu;
204                
205                int totalRed = 0;       // sum of all pixel component values represented by this node
206                int totalGrn = 0;
207                int totalBlu = 0;
208                
209                int colorIdx = -1;      // the index of the associated color in the final color table
210
211                TreeNode(TreeNode parent, int id) {
212                        this.parent = parent;
213                        this.id = id;
214                        this.childs = new TreeNode[8];
215                        nodeCnt++;
216
217                        if (parent == null) {   // this is the root node
218                                this.level = 0;
219                                // set this node's midpoint
220                                int mid = (MAX_RGB + 1) / 2;
221                                midRed = mid;
222                                midGrn = mid;
223                                midBlu = mid;
224                        }
225                        else {
226                                this.level = parent.level + 1;
227                                // attach this node to its parent
228                                parent.nChilds++;
229                                parent.childs[id] = this;
230                                // set this node's midpoint
231                                //int bi = (1 << (MAX_TREE_DEPTH - level)) >> 1;
232                                int bi = 256 >> (level + 1);
233                                midRed = parent.midRed + ((id & 1) > 0 ? bi : -bi);
234                                midGrn = parent.midGrn + ((id & 2) > 0 ? bi : -bi);
235                                midBlu = parent.midBlu + ((id & 4) > 0 ? bi : -bi);
236                                if (level == depth) {   // this is a leaf node
237                                        colorCnt++;
238                                }
239                        }
240                }
241
242
243                /**
244                 * Prune all nodes at the lowest level (= depth) of the tree.
245                 */
246                void pruneTree() {
247                        if (nChilds != 0) {     
248                                // move recursively to the lowest level
249                                for (int i = 0; i < childs.length; i++) {
250                                        if (childs[i] != null) {
251                                                childs[i].pruneTree();
252                                        }
253                                }
254                        }
255                        // work on the actual node now
256                        if (level == depth) {   // we are at a node on the lowest level
257                                delete();                       // remove THIS node!
258                        }
259                }
260
261
262                /**
263                 * Removes any nodes that hold fewer than 'minPixelCount' pixels
264                 * and finds the minimum population of all remaining nodes. 
265                 * 
266                 * @param minPixelCount The minimum population required for surviving nodes.
267                 * @param newMinPixelCnt The minimum population found so far (during recursive tree walk).
268                 * @return
269                 */
270                int reduceSparseNodes(int minPixelCount, int newMinPixelCnt) {
271                        // visit all child nodes first
272                        if (nChilds > 0) {
273                                for (TreeNode ch : childs) {
274                                        if (ch != null) {
275                                                newMinPixelCnt = ch.reduceSparseNodes(minPixelCount, newMinPixelCnt);
276                                        }
277                                }
278                        }
279                        // work on the actual node now
280                        if (nPixels <= minPixelCount) {
281                                this.delete();
282                        } 
283                        else {
284                                if (nUnique > 0) {
285                                        colorCnt++;
286                                }
287                                newMinPixelCnt = Math.min(nPixels, newMinPixelCnt); // find smallest population
288                        }
289                        return newMinPixelCnt;
290                }
291                
292                /**
293                 * Remove this node, and push all pixel statistics to its parent.
294                 */
295                void delete() {
296                        parent.nChilds--;
297                        parent.nUnique += nUnique;
298                        parent.totalRed += totalRed;
299                        parent.totalGrn += totalGrn;
300                        parent.totalBlu += totalBlu;
301                        parent.childs[id] = null;       // unlink
302                        nodeCnt--;
303                }
304                
305                /**
306                 * Calculates the branch index [0,...,7] out of this node
307                 * for the specified color.
308                 * @param red
309                 * @param grn
310                 * @param blu
311                 * @return The branch index [0,...,7].
312                 */
313                int getChildId(int[] rgb) {
314                        int idx = 0;
315                        if (rgb[0] > this.midRed) idx = idx | 0X01;
316                        if (rgb[1] > this.midGrn) idx = idx | 0X02;
317                        if (rgb[2] > this.midBlu) idx = idx | 0X04;
318                        return idx;
319                }
320                
321//              int getChildId(int[] rgb) {
322//                      int idx = ((rgb[0] > this.midRed ? 1 : 0) << 0) 
323//                                      | ((rgb[1] > this.midGrn ? 1 : 0) << 1)
324//                                      | ((rgb[2] > this.midBlu ? 1 : 0) << 2);
325//                      return idx;
326//              }
327                
328                /**
329                 * Collects the color entries for the color map. Any node
330                 * with a non-zero number of unique colors creates a color map
331                 * entry. The representative color for the node is calculated
332                 * as the average color vector over all contributing pixels.
333                 * 
334                 * @param colList List of colors to add to.
335                 */
336                private void collectColors(List<float[]> colList) {
337                        // visit all children first
338                        if (nChilds > 0) {
339                                for (TreeNode ch : childs) {
340                                        if (ch != null) {
341                                                ch.collectColors(colList);
342                                        }
343                                }
344                        }               
345                        // process this node
346//                      System.out.println("collectColors " + this.id + " unique=" + this.nUnique);
347                        if (nUnique > 0) {                      
348                                float avgRed = (float) totalRed / nUnique;
349                                float avgGrn = (float) totalGrn / nUnique;
350                                float avgBlu = (float) totalBlu / nUnique;
351                                colList.add(new float[] {avgRed, avgGrn, avgBlu});
352                                this.colorIdx = colorCnt;       // store the color table index for this node
353                                colorCnt++;
354                        }
355                }
356
357                private void listNodes() {
358                        if (nChilds > 0) {      
359                                for (TreeNode ch : childs) {
360                                        if (ch != null) {
361                                                ch.listNodes();
362                                        }
363                                }
364                        }
365                        // bottom of recursion
366//                      System.out.format(makeBlanks(level) + "node level=%d unique=%d total=%d: %3d %3d %3d, \n", 
367//                                      level, nUnique, this.nPixels, 0xFF & midRed, 0xFF & midGrn, 0xFF & midBlu); 
368                }
369                
370                private String makeBlanks(int level) {
371                        char[] blanks = new char[3 * level];
372                        Arrays.fill(blanks, '-');
373                        return new String(blanks);
374                }
375        }
376        
377        // ------- methods required by abstract super class -----------------------
378        
379        @Override
380        public float[][] getColorMap() {
381                return makeColorMap();
382        }
383        
384        @Override
385        public int findColorIndex(int p, float[][] colormap) {
386                if (this.quickQuantization) {
387                        return getNodeIndex(p);
388                }
389                else {
390                        return ColorQuantizer.super.findColorIndex(p, colormap);
391                }
392        }
393
394        /**
395         * Finds the associated color table index for the supplied RGB color
396         * by traversing the octree. 
397         * @param p
398         * @return
399         */
400        private int getNodeIndex(int p) {
401                int[] rgb = RgbUtils.intToRgb(p);
402                TreeNode node = root;
403                while(true) {
404                        int id = node.getChildId(rgb);  // which of the child nodes?
405                        if (node.childs[id] == null) {  // there is no finer-grained child node, so current 'node' is the one
406                                break;
407                        }
408                        node = node.childs[id];
409                }
410                // 'node' is associated with color p
411                if (node.colorIdx < 0) {
412                        throw new RuntimeException("cannot assign color " + p);
413                }
414                return node.colorIdx;
415        }
416        
417        private int log2(int n){
418                if(n <= 0) throw new IllegalArgumentException();
419                return 31 - Integer.numberOfLeadingZeros(n);
420        }
421        
422        // -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
423
424        public static void main(String[] args) {
425//              String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/alps-01s.png";
426                String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/desaturation-hsv/balls.jpg";
427//              String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/single-color.png";
428//              String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/two-colors.png";
429//              String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/random-colors.png";
430//              String path = "D:/svn-book/Book/img/ch-color-images/ramp-fire.png";
431                
432                int K = 16; 
433                System.out.println("image = " + path);
434                System.out.println("K = " + K);
435
436                ImagePlus im = IJ.openImage(path);
437                if (im == null) {
438                        System.out.println("could not open: " + path);
439                        return;
440                }
441                
442                ImageProcessor ip = im.getProcessor();
443                ColorProcessor cp = ip.convertToColorProcessor();
444                
445                // MedianCutQuantizer quantizer = new MedianCutQuantizer(cp, K);
446
447                OctreeQuantizer quantizer = new OctreeQuantizer(cp, K);
448                quantizer.setQuickQuantization(false);
449        
450                quantizer.listColorMap();
451                
452                System.out.println("quantizing image");
453                ByteProcessor qi = quantizer.quantize(cp);
454                System.out.println("showing image");
455                (new ImagePlus("quantizez", qi)).show();
456                
457        }
458}
459
460/*
461%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
462%                                                                             %
463%                                                                             %
464%                                                                             %
465%           QQQ   U   U   AAA   N   N  TTTTT  IIIII   ZZZZZ  EEEEE            %
466%          Q   Q  U   U  A   A  NN  N    T      I        ZZ  E                %
467%          Q   Q  U   U  AAAAA  N N N    T      I      ZZZ   EEEEE            %
468%          Q  QQ  U   U  A   A  N  NN    T      I     ZZ     E                %
469%           QQQQ   UUU   A   A  N   N    T    IIIII   ZZZZZ  EEEEE            %
470%                                                                             %
471%                                                                             %
472%              Reduce the Number of Unique Colors in an Image                 %
473%                                                                             %
474%                                                                             %
475%                           Software Design                                   %
476%                             John Cristy                                     %
477%                              July 1992                                      %
478%                                                                             %
479%                                                                             %
480%  Copyright 1998 E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company                        %
481%                                                                             %
482%  Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a    %
483%  copy of this software and associated documentation files ("ImageMagick"),  %
484%  to deal in ImageMagick without restriction, including without limitation   %
485%  the rights to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense,   %
486%  and/or sell copies of ImageMagick, and to permit persons to whom the       %
487%  ImageMagick is furnished to do so, subject to the following conditions:    %
488%                                                                             %
489%  The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in %
490%  all copies or substantial portions of ImageMagick.                         %
491%                                                                             %
492%  The software is provided "as is", without warranty of any kind, express or %
493%  implied, including but not limited to the warranties of merchantability,   %
494%  fitness for a particular purpose and noninfringement.  In no event shall   %
495%  E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company be liable for any claim, damages or   %
496%  other liability, whether in an action of contract, tort or otherwise,      %
497%  arising from, out of or in connection with ImageMagick or the use or other %
498%  dealings in ImageMagick.                                                   %
499%                                                                             %
500%  Except as contained in this notice, the name of the E. I. du Pont de       %
501%  Nemours and Company shall not be used in advertising or otherwise to       %
502%  promote the sale, use or other dealings in ImageMagick without prior       %
503%  written authorization from the E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company.       %
504%                                                                             %
505%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
506%
507%  Realism in computer graphics typically requires using 24 bits/pixel to
508%  generate an image. Yet many graphic display devices do not contain
509%  the amount of memory necessary to match the spatial and color
510%  resolution of the human eye. The QUANTIZE program takes a 24 bit
511%  image and reduces the number of colors so it can be displayed on
512%  raster device with less bits per pixel. In most instances, the
513%  quantized image closely resembles the original reference image.
514%
515%  A reduction of colors in an image is also desirable for image
516%  transmission and real-time animation.
517%
518%  Function Quantize takes a standard RGB or monochrome images and quantizes
519%  them down to some fixed number of colors.
520%
521%  For purposes of color allocation, an image is a set of n pixels, where
522%  each pixel is a point in RGB space. RGB space is a 3-dimensional
523%  vector space, and each pixel, pi, is defined by an ordered triple of
524%  red, green, and blue coordinates, (ri, gi, bi).
525%
526%  Each primary color component (red, green, or blue) represents an
527%  intensity which varies linearly from 0 to a maximum value, cmax, which
528%  corresponds to full saturation of that color. Color allocation is
529%  defined over a domain consisting of the cube in RGB space with
530%  opposite vertices at (0,0,0) and (cmax,cmax,cmax). QUANTIZE requires
531%  cmax = 255.
532%
533%  The algorithm maps this domain onto a tree in which each node
534%  represents a cube within that domain. In the following discussion
535%  these cubes are defined by the coordinate of two opposite vertices:
536%  The vertex nearest the origin in RGB space and the vertex farthest
537%  from the origin.
538%
539%  The tree's root node represents the the entire domain, (0,0,0) through
540%  (cmax,cmax,cmax). Each lower level in the tree is generated by
541%  subdividing one node's cube into eight smaller cubes of equal size.
542%  This corresponds to bisecting the parent cube with planes passing
543%  through the midpoints of each edge.
544%
545%  The basic algorithm operates in three phases: Classification,
546%  Reduction, and Assignment. Classification builds a color
547%  description tree for the image. Reduction collapses the tree until
548%  the number it represents, at most, the number of colors desired in the
549%  output image. Assignment defines the output image's color map and
550%  sets each pixel's color by reclassification in the reduced tree.
551%  Our goal is to minimize the numerical discrepancies between the original
552%  colors and quantized colors (quantization error).
553%
554%  Classification begins by initializing a color description tree of
555%  sufficient depth to represent each possible input color in a leaf.
556%  However, it is impractical to generate a fully-formed color
557%  description tree in the classification phase for realistic values of
558%  cmax. If colors components in the input image are quantized to k-bit
559%  precision, so that cmax= 2k-1, the tree would need k levels below the
560%  root node to allow representing each possible input color in a leaf.
561%  This becomes prohibitive because the tree's total number of nodes is
562%  1 + sum(i=1,k,8k).
563%
564%  A complete tree would require 19,173,961 nodes for k = 8, cmax = 255.
565%  Therefore, to avoid building a fully populated tree, QUANTIZE: (1)
566%  Initializes data structures for nodes only as they are needed;  (2)
567%  Chooses a maximum depth for the tree as a function of the desired
568%  number of colors in the output image (currently log2(colormap size)).
569%
570%  For each pixel in the input image, classification scans downward from
571%  the root of the color description tree. At each level of the tree it
572%  identifies the single node which represents a cube in RGB space
573%  containing the pixel's color. It updates the following data for each
574%  such node:
575%
576%    n1: Number of pixels whose color is contained in the RGB cube
577%    which this node represents;
578%
579%    n2: Number of pixels whose color is not represented in a node at
580%    lower depth in the tree;  initially,  n2 = 0 for all nodes except
581%    leaves of the tree.
582%
583%    Sr, Sg, Sb: Sums of the red, green, and blue component values for
584%    all pixels not classified at a lower depth. The combination of
585%    these sums and n2  will ultimately characterize the mean color of a
586%    set of pixels represented by this node.
587%
588%    E: The distance squared in RGB space between each pixel contained
589%    within a node and the nodes' center. This represents the quantization
590%    error for a node.
591%
592%  Reduction repeatedly prunes the tree until the number of nodes with
593%  n2 > 0 is less than or equal to the maximum number of colors allowed
594%  in the output image. On any given iteration over the tree, it selects
595%  those nodes whose E count is minimal for pruning and merges their
596%  color statistics upward. It uses a pruning threshold, Ep, to govern
597%  node selection as follows:
598%
599%    Ep = 0
600%    while number of nodes with (n2 > 0) > required maximum number of colors
601%      prune all nodes such that E <= Ep
602%      Set Ep to minimum E in remaining nodes
603%
604%  This has the effect of minimizing any quantization error when merging
605%  two nodes together.
606%
607%  When a node to be pruned has offspring, the pruning procedure invokes
608%  itself recursively in order to prune the tree from the leaves upward.
609%  n2,  Sr, Sg,  and  Sb in a node being pruned are always added to the
610%  corresponding data in that node's parent. This retains the pruned
611%  node's color characteristics for later averaging.
612%
613%  For each node, n2 pixels exist for which that node represents the
614%  smallest volume in RGB space containing those pixel's colors. When n2
615%  > 0 the node will uniquely define a color in the output image. At the
616%  beginning of reduction,  n2 = 0  for all nodes except a the leaves of
617%  the tree which represent colors present in the input image.
618%
619%  The other pixel count, n1, indicates the total number of colors
620%  within the cubic volume which the node represents. This includes n1 -
621%  n2  pixels whose colors should be defined by nodes at a lower level in
622%  the tree.
623%
624%  Assignment generates the output image from the pruned tree. The
625%  output image consists of two parts: (1)  A color map, which is an
626%  array of color descriptions (RGB triples) for each color present in
627%  the output image;  (2)  A pixel array, which represents each pixel as
628%  an index into the color map array.
629%
630%  First, the assignment phase makes one pass over the pruned color
631%  description tree to establish the image's color map. For each node
632%  with n2  > 0, it divides Sr, Sg, and Sb by n2 . This produces the
633%  mean color of all pixels that classify no lower than this node. Each
634%  of these colors becomes an entry in the color map.
635%
636%  Finally,  the assignment phase reclassifies each pixel in the pruned
637%  tree to identify the deepest node containing the pixel's color. The
638%  pixel's value in the pixel array becomes the index of this node's mean
639%  color in the color map.
640%
641%  With the permission of USC Information Sciences Institute, 4676 Admiralty
642%  Way, Marina del Rey, California  90292, this code was adapted from module
643%  ALCOLS written by Paul Raveling.
644%
645%  The names of ISI and USC are not used in advertising or publicity
646%  pertaining to distribution of the software without prior specific
647%  written permission from ISI.
648%
649*/
